title: 107_hr3112
content: The Act titled "Back to Work Act of 2001" authorizes National Emergency Grants in response to the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. The "Back to Work Act of 2001" authorizes National Emergency Grants for providing employment and training assistance to workers affected by major economic dislocations caused by the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. The "Back to Work Act of 2001" allows Governors to apply for grants to assist workers affected by the 9/11 attacks. Governors must certify that the attacks led to economic disruptions in their state. Local workforce boards can administer the grants. Participant eligibility is also outlined. Participant eligibility for assistance under the "Back to Work Act of 2001" requires individuals to be certified as dislocated workers due to the 9/11 attacks. Assistance includes employment and training support, as well as temporary health care coverage. Temporary health care coverage assistance is provided to qualified individuals who are dislocated workers certified by the Governor. Health care coverage premium assistance, established by the Governor, provides up to 75% of the premium for health care coverage for dislocated workers for the first 10 months. The Governor established health care coverage premium assistance, providing up to 75% of the premium for dislocated workers for the first 10 months. This subsection does not establish entitlement to premium assistance for qualified individuals. Definitions for health care coverage exclude certain types of coverage under specific titles of the Social Security Act. The term "health care coverage" excludes specific types of coverage under titles of the Social Security Act, United States Code, and the Indian Health Care Improvement Act, as well as coverage under a qualified long-term care insurance contract. The term "premium" in health care coverage refers to the cost of coverage. $3,000,000,000 is authorized for grants in fiscal year 2002 under subsection (a)(4). The additional amounts authorized under this subsection are in addition to funds available under other provisions of law and remain available for 18 months after enactment. Sense of Congress to promote services under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 was enacted to provide assistance for workers who have been laid off, including job training services like one-stop career centers and individual training accounts. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 provides job training vouchers for individuals and rapid response services for workers during mass layoffs. Congress encourages Americans to utilize services under the Act. To assist workers during unemployment, utilize services under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998.
